description.para: Functions for working with transactions.

briefdescription.para: Create a new transaction from the serialized data.

simplesect.para: The transaction, or null on error.

briefdescription.para: Copy a transaction. Transactions are reference counted, so this just increments the reference count.
Serializes the transaction through the passed in callback to bytes. This is consensus serialization that is also used for the P2P network.

parameterdescription.para: Non-null, callback to a write bytes function.
Holds a user-defined opaque structure that will be passed back through the writer callback.

memberdef.name: btck_transaction_count_outputs

briefdescription.para: Get the number of outputs of a transaction.
Get the transaction outputs at the provided index. The returned transaction output is not owned and depends on the lifetime of the transaction.

parameterdescription.para: The index of the transaction output to be retrieved.

briefdescription.para: Get the transaction input at the provided index. The returned transaction input is not owned and depends on the lifetime of the transaction.

parameterdescription.para: The index of the transaction input to be retrieved.

briefdescription.para: Get the number of inputs of a transaction.
Get the txid of a transaction. The returned txid is not owned and depends on the lifetime of the transaction.

description.para: Functions for working with script pubkeys.

briefdescription.para: Create a script pubkey from serialized data.

parameterdescription.para: Length of the script pubkey data.

briefdescription.para: Copy a script pubkey.

memberdef.argsstring: (const btck_ScriptPubkey *script_pubkey, int64_t amount, const btck_Transaction *tx_to, const btck_TransactionOutput **spent_outputs, size_t spent_outputs_len, unsigned int input_index, btck_ScriptVerificationFlags flags, btck_ScriptVerifyStatus *status) BITCOINKERNEL_ARG_NONNULL(1
memberdef.name: btck_script_pubkey_verify

briefdescription.para: Verify if the input at input_index of tx_to spends the script pubkey under the constraints specified by flags. If the btck_ScriptVerificationFlags_WITNESS flag is set in the flags bitfield, the amount parameter is used. If the taproot flag is set, the spent outputs parameter is used to validate taproot transactions.

parameterdescription.para: Non-null, script pubkey to be spent.
Amount of the script pubkey's associated output. May be zero if the witness flag is not set.
Nullable if the taproot flag is not set. Points to an array of outputs spent by the transaction.
Index of the input in tx_to spending the script_pubkey.
Bitfield of btck_ScriptVerificationFlags controlling validation constraints.
Nullable, will be set to an error code if the operation fails, or OK otherwise.

simplesect.para: 1 if the script is valid, 0 otherwise.

memberdef.definition: BITCOINKERNEL_API int BITCOINKERNEL_WARN_UNUSED_RESULT BITCOINKERNEL_API int btck_script_pubkey_to_bytes
memberdef.name: btck_script_pubkey_to_bytes

briefdescription.para: Serializes the script pubkey through the passed in callback to bytes.

parameterdescription.para: Non-null, callback to a write bytes function.
Holds a user-defined opaque structure that will be passed back through the writer callback.

description.para: Functions for working with transaction outputs.

briefdescription.para: Create a transaction output from a script pubkey and an amount.

parameterdescription.para: The amount associated with the script pubkey for this output.

briefdescription.para: Get the script pubkey of the output. The returned script pubkey is not owned and depends on the lifetime of the transaction output.
Get the amount in the output.
Copy a transaction output.

detaileddescription.para: Destroy the transaction output.

description.para: Logging-related functions.

briefdescription.para: This disables the global internal logger. No log messages will be buffered internally anymore once this is called and the buffer is cleared. This function should only be called once and is not thread or re-entry safe. Log messages will be buffered until this function is called, or a logging connection is created. This must not be called while a logging connection already exists.
Set some options for the global internal logger. This changes global settings and will override settings for all existing btck_LoggingConnection instances.

parameterdescription.para: Sets formatting options of the log messages.

briefdescription.para: Set the log level of the global internal logger. This does not enable the selected categories. Use btck_logging_enable_category to start logging from a specific, or all categories. This changes a global setting and will override settings for all existing btck_LoggingConnection instances.

parameterdescription.para: If btck_LogCategory_ALL is chosen, sets both the global fallback log level used by all categories that don't have a specific level set, and also sets the log level for messages logged with the btck_LogCategory_ALL category itself. For any other category, sets a category-specific log level that overrides the global fallback for that category only.
Log level at which the log category is set.

briefdescription.para: Enable a specific log category for the global internal logger. This changes a global setting and will override settings for all existing btck_LoggingConnection instances.

parameterdescription.para: If btck_LogCategory_ALL is chosen, all categories will be enabled.

briefdescription.para: Disable a specific log category for the global internal logger. This changes a global setting and will override settings for all existing btck_LoggingConnection instances.

parameterdescription.para: If btck_LogCategory_ALL is chosen, all categories will be disabled.

briefdescription.para: Start logging messages through the provided callback. Log messages produced before this function is first called are buffered and on calling this function are logged immediately.

parameterdescription.para: Non-null, function through which messages will be logged.

Nullable, holds a user-defined opaque structure. Is passed back to the user through the callback. If the user_data_destroy_callback is also defined it is assumed that ownership of the user_data is passed to the created logging connection.
Nullable, function for freeing the user data.

simplesect.para: A new kernel logging connection, or null on error.

detaileddescription.para: Stop logging and destroy the logging connection.

description.para: Functions for working with chain parameters.

briefdescription.para: Creates a chain parameters struct with default parameters based on the passed in chain type.

parameterdescription.para: Controls the chain parameters type created.

simplesect.para: An allocated chain parameters opaque struct.

detaileddescription.para: Copy the chain parameters.
Destroy the chain parameters.

description.para: Functions for working with context options.

detaileddescription.para: Creates an empty context options.

briefdescription.para: Sets the chain params for the context options. The context created with the options will be configured for these chain parameters.

parameterdescription.para: Is set to the context options.

briefdescription.para: Set the kernel notifications for the context options. The context created with the options will be configured with these notifications.

parameterdescription.para: Is set to the context options.

briefdescription.para: Set the validation interface callbacks for the context options. The context created with the options will be configured for these validation interface callbacks. The callbacks will then be triggered from validation events issued by the chainstate manager created from the same context.

parameterdescription.para: The callbacks used for passing validation information to the user.

detaileddescription.para: Destroy the context options.

description.para: Functions for working with contexts.

briefdescription.para: Create a new kernel context. If the options have not been previously set, their corresponding fields will be initialized to default values; the context will assume mainnet chain parameters and won't attempt to call the kernel notification callbacks.

simplesect.para: The allocated context, or null on error.

detaileddescription.para: Copy the context.

briefdescription.para: Interrupt can be used to halt long-running validation functions like when reindexing, importing or processing blocks.

simplesect.para: 0 if the interrupt was successful, non-zero otherwise.

detaileddescription.para: Destroy the context.

description.para: Functions for working with block tree entries.

briefdescription.para: Returns the previous block tree entry in the tree, or null if the current block tree entry is the genesis block.

simplesect.para: The previous block tree entry, or null on error or if the current block tree entry is the genesis block.

briefdescription.para: Return the height of a certain block tree entry.
Return the block hash associated with a block tree entry.
Check if two block tree entries are equal. Two block tree entries are equal when they point to the same block.

simplesect.para: 1 if the block tree entries are equal, 0 otherwise.

description.para: Functions for working with chainstate manager options.

memberdef.argsstring: (const btck_Context *context, const char *data_directory, size_t data_directory_len, const char *blocks_directory, size_t blocks_directory_len) BITCOINKERNEL_ARG_NONNULL(1)
memberdef.name: btck_chainstate_manager_options_create

briefdescription.para: Create options for the chainstate manager.

parameterdescription.para: Non-null, the created options and through it the chainstate manager will associate with this kernel context for the duration of their lifetimes.
Non-null, non-empty path string of the directory containing the chainstate data. If the directory does not exist yet, it will be created.
Non-null, non-empty path string of the directory containing the block data. If the directory does not exist yet, it will be created.

simplesect.para: The allocated chainstate manager options, or null on error.

briefdescription.para: Set the number of available worker threads used during validation.

parameterdescription.para: The number of worker threads that should be spawned in the thread pool used for validation. When set to 0 no parallel verification is done. The value range is clamped internally between 0 and 15.

briefdescription.para: Sets wipe db in the options. In combination with calling btck_chainstate_manager_import_blocks this triggers either a full reindex, or a reindex of just the chainstate database.

parameterdescription.para: Set wipe block tree db. Should only be 1 if wipe_chainstate_db is 1 too.

simplesect.para: 0 if the set was successful, non-zero if the set failed.

briefdescription.para: Sets block tree db in memory in the options.

parameterdescription.para: Set block tree db in memory.

briefdescription.para: Sets chainstate db in memory in the options.

detaileddescription.para: Destroy the chainstate manager options.

description.para: Functions for chainstate management.

briefdescription.para: Create a chainstate manager. This is the main object for many validation tasks as well as for retrieving data from the chain and interacting with its chainstate and indexes.

simplesect.para: The allocated chainstate manager, or null on error.

memberdef.argsstring: (btck_ChainstateManager *chainstate_manager, const char **block_file_paths_data, size_t *block_file_paths_lens, size_t block_file_paths_data_len) BITCOINKERNEL_ARG_NONNULL(1)
memberdef.name: btck_chainstate_manager_import_blocks

briefdescription.para: Triggers the start of a reindex if the wipe options were previously set for the chainstate manager. Can also import an array of existing block files selected by the user.

parameterdescription.para: Nullable, array of block files described by their full filesystem paths.
Nullable, array containing the lengths of each of the paths.
Length of the block_file_paths_data and block_file_paths_len arrays.

simplesect.para: 0 if the import blocks call was completed successfully, non-zero otherwise.

briefdescription.para: Process and validate the passed in block with the chainstate manager. Processing first does checks on the block, and if these passed, saves it to disk. It then validates the block against the utxo set. If it is valid, the chain is extended with it. The return value is not indicative of the block's validity. Detailed information on the validity of the block can be retrieved by registering the block_checked callback in the validation interface.

parameterdescription.para: Nullable, will be set to 1 if this block was not processed before. Note that this means it might also not be 1 if processing was attempted before, but the block was found invalid before its data was persisted.

simplesect.para: 0 if processing the block was successful. Will also return 0 for valid, but duplicate blocks.

memberdef.type: BITCOINKERNEL_API int BITCOINKERNEL_WARN_UNUSED_RESULT BITCOINKERNEL_API const btck_Chain *BITCOINKERNEL_WARN_UNUSED_RESULT
memberdef.definition: BITCOINKERNEL_API int BITCOINKERNEL_WARN_UNUSED_RESULT BITCOINKERNEL_API const btck_Chain *BITCOINKERNEL_WARN_UNUSED_RESULT btck_chainstate_manager_get_active_chain
memberdef.name: btck_chainstate_manager_get_active_chain

briefdescription.para: Returns the best known currently active chain. Its lifetime is dependent on the chainstate manager. It can be thought of as a view on a vector of block tree entries that form the best chain. The returned chain reference always points to the currently active best chain. However, state transitions within the chainstate manager (e.g., processing blocks) will update the chain's contents. Data retrieved from this chain is only consistent up to the point when new data is processed in the chainstate manager. It is the user's responsibility to guard against these inconsistencies.
Retrieve a block tree entry by its block hash.

simplesect.para: The block tree entry of the block with the passed in hash, or null if the block hash is not found.

BITCOINKERNEL_ARG_NONNULL is a compiler attribute used to indicate that certain pointer arguments to a function are not expected to be null.

Callers must not pass a null pointer for arguments marked with this attribute, as doing so may result in undefined behavior. This attribute should only be used for arguments where a null pointer is unambiguously a programmer error, such as for opaque handles, and not for pointers to raw input data that might validly be null (e.g., from an empty std::span or std::string).

briefdescription.para: initial value. Block has not yet been rejected
invalid by consensus rules (excluding any below reasons)
this block was cached as being invalid and we didn't store the reason why
invalid proof of work or time too old
the block's data didn't match the data committed to by the PoW
We don't have the previous block the checked one is built on.
A block this one builds on is invalid.
block timestamp was > 2 hours in the future (or our clock is bad)
the block header may be on a too-little-work chain
The flags were combined in an invalid way.
The taproot flag was set, so valid spent_outputs have to be provided.
evaluate P2SH (BIP16) subscripts
enforce strict DER (BIP66) compliance
enforce NULLDUMMY (BIP147)
enable CHECKLOCKTIMEVERIFY (BIP65)
enable CHECKSEQUENCEVERIFY (BIP112)
enable WITNESS (BIP141)
enable TAPROOT (BIPs 341 & 342)

detaileddescription.para: Opaque data structure for holding a transaction.
Opaque data structure for holding a script pubkey.
Opaque data structure for holding a transaction output.
Opaque data structure for holding a logging connection.
The logging connection can be used to manually stop logging.

Messages that were logged before a connection is created are buffered in a 1MB buffer. Logging can alternatively be permanently disabled by calling btck_logging_disable. Functions changing the logging settings are global and change the settings for all existing btck_LoggingConnection instances.
Opaque data structure for holding the chain parameters.

These are eventually placed into a kernel context through the kernel context options. The parameters describe the properties of a chain, and may be instantiated for either mainnet, testnet, signet, or regtest.
Opaque data structure for holding options for creating a new kernel context.

Once a kernel context has been created from these options, they may be destroyed. The options hold the notification and validation interface callbacks as well as the selected chain type until they are passed to the context. If no options are configured, the context will be instantiated with no callbacks and for mainnet. Their content and scope can be expanded over time.
Opaque data structure for holding a kernel context.

The kernel context is used to initialize internal state and hold the chain parameters and callbacks for handling error and validation events. Once other validation objects are instantiated from it, the context is kept in memory for the duration of their lifetimes.
The processing of validation events is done through an internal task runner owned by the context. It passes events through the registered validation interface callbacks.
A constructed context can be safely used from multiple threads.
Opaque data structure for holding a block tree entry.

This is a pointer to an element in the block index currently in memory of the chainstate manager. It is valid for the lifetime of the chainstate manager it was retrieved from. The entry is part of a tree-like structure that is maintained internally. Every entry, besides the genesis, points to a single parent. Multiple entries may share a parent, thus forming a tree. Each entry corresponds to a single block and may be used to retrieve its data and validation status.
Opaque data structure for holding options for creating a new chainstate manager.
The chainstate manager options are used to set some parameters for the chainstate manager.
Opaque data structure for holding a chainstate manager.
The chainstate manager is the central object for doing validation tasks as well as retrieving data from the chain. Internally it is a complex data structure with diverse functionality.
Its functionality will be more and more exposed in the future.
Opaque data structure for holding a block.
Opaque data structure for holding the state of a block during validation.
Contains information indicating whether validation was successful, and if not which step during block validation failed.
Opaque data structure for holding the currently known best-chain associated with a chainstate.
Opaque data structure for holding a block's spent outputs.

Contains all the previous outputs consumed by all transactions in a specific block. Internally it holds a nested vector. The top level vector has an entry for each transaction in a block (in order of the actual transactions of the block and without the coinbase transaction). This is exposed through btck_TransactionSpentOutputs. Each btck_TransactionSpentOutputs is in turn a vector of all the previous outputs of a transaction (in order of their corresponding inputs).
Opaque data structure for holding a transaction's spent outputs.
Holds the coins consumed by a certain transaction. Retrieved through the btck_BlockSpentOutputs. The coins are in the same order as the transaction's inputs consuming them.
Opaque data structure for holding a coin.
Holds information on the btck_TransactionOutput held within, including the height it was spent at and whether it is a coinbase output.
Opaque data structure for holding a block hash.
This is a type-safe identifier for a block.
Opaque data structure for holding a transaction input.
Holds information on the btck_TransactionOutPoint held within.
Opaque data structure for holding a transaction out point.
Holds the txid and output index it is pointing to.
Current sync state passed to tip changed callbacks.
Possible warning types issued by validation.

detaileddescription.para: Function signature for serializing data.
Whether a validated data structure is valid, invalid, or an error was encountered during processing.
A granular "reason" why a block was invalid.
A collection of logging categories that may be encountered by kernel code.
The level at which logs should be produced.
A collection of status codes that may be issued by the script verify function.
Script verification flags that may be composed with each other.
